Twitter        Facebook     Windows Live     Yahoo                 MySpace     Email                   Bread Crumbs                Home          >           Academics          >           Courses          >           Course Detail                                        Hip-Hop Trails: Tracing and Rediscovering the Origins and Legacy of Hip-Hop Culture                                Semester and Year        FA 2013                    Course Number        CLI-UG1436                    Section        001                    Instructor        Martha Diaz                    Days                            Fri                                 Time                            3:30 PM -       6:10 PM                                Units        4.0                    Level        U                    Foundation Requirement                                                  Description       There is no doubt that Hip-Hop is ubiquitous through radio and television commercials, music videos, films, magazines, billboards, and video games. However, the Hip-Hop we see today is not the same Hip-Hop that we saw when early pioneers formed a distinct sub-culture (encompassing MCing, Beatboxing, DJing, bboying, and graffiti) to speak to the experiences of disenfranchised youth across the world. Commercialization has created two kinds of Hip-Hop: one is focused on the community and connected to a long legacy and history of Black/Caribbean experience, and a second focused on individualism and celebrating instant gratification, funded by big corporations to sell brands and consumption as a lifestyle. What determining factors caused this evolution and what does it mean? This course traces Hip-Hop’s history and its influences through participatory action research, media literacy, and service learning. Students will learn to analyze, interpret, chronicle, and sample Hip-Hop. In collaboration with The Schomburg Center’s Hip-Hop 4.0 Initiative (Education, Creativity, Community, and Legacy), and other institutions/organizations in the New York area (such as the Hip-Hop Education Center, Graffiti Hall of Fame), students will have access to Hip-Hop repositories, lectures, panel discussions, film screenings, and guest speakers. Students will also work on the first major exhibition celebrating Hip-Hop's 40th anniversary at the Schomburg Center. Books include:  Yes, Yes Ya’ll  by Jim Fricke and Charlie Ahearn,  Hip-Hop Generation  by Bakari Kitwana,  The Tanning of America  by Steve Stoute and  That’s The Joint!  by Murray Forman and Marc Anthony Neal.                              Time                            3:30 PM -       6:10 PM                                Units        4.0                    Level        U                    Foundation Requirement                                                  Description       There is no doubt that Hip-Hop is ubiquitous through radio and television commercials, music videos, films, magazines, Technorati     Twitter        Facebook     Windows Live     Yahoo                 MySpace     Email                    Bread Crumbs                Home          >           Academics          >           Faculty          >           Martha Diaz                               Martha Diaz                                                           Part-time Faculty      B.A. Communications, Fairleigh Dickinson University, 1992           Martha Diaz is a community organizer, educator, media producer, archivist and social entrepreneur. She has been dedicated to advancing social justice, cultivating leaders and artists, and mentoring youth for over 15 years. She was a production assistant for the late Ted Demme, the TV and film producer/director behind  Yo! MTV Raps  (1988)  , Life  (1999)  , Blow  (2001)   and  A Decade Under the Influence  (2003). In 1999, Diaz produced and directed,  H2O [Hip-Hop Odyssey]  , a short documentary on the evolution and global impact of Hip-Hop culture. In 2002, Diaz formed the H2O International Film Festival and subsequently developed the Hip-Hop Association [H2A]. For seven years, Diaz served as president and executive director of the H2A; she is currently its chair. Diaz launched  H2ONewsreel  , the first Hip-Hop media distribution label dedicated to the education field, in collaboration with Third World Newsreel. Diaz co-created and edited the  Hip-Hop Education Guidebook Series  with Marcella Runell Hall.   In 2008, she launched the  Womanhood Learning Project  as an intervention strategy to empower women in Hip-Hop,   and she is the editor of the forthcoming book,  Fresh, Bold and So Def: Women In Hip-Hop Changing The Game,  with Dr. Irma McClaurin and Dr. Rachel Raimist  .  As a resident of NJPAC’s Alternate Routes Residency Program, Diaz developed the  Ladies First Fund,  the first micro-grant for women social entrepreneurs. As a 2008 NYU Gallatin Graduate student and a Catherine B. Reynolds Fellow, she founded the  Hip-Hop Education Center for Research, Evaluation and Training,  in partnership with Dr. Pedro Noguera of the Metropolitan Center for Urban Education at NYU’s Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Behavior.                News       Professor Martha Diaz spoke in April 2014 in Washington, DC, at the One Mic Festival at the Kennedy Center on Remixing Hip-Hop Education and Hip-Hop Feminism. She was the associate producer for the documentary Time Is Illmatic , which was selected to open the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival.                           top of page                                     Contact Information     Martha Diaz             Part-time Faculty              martha.diaz@nyu.edu             1 Wash Pl, Room 608             (212) 998-7361      Download as vCard                       Office Hours                     Thursday (5-6 by appt)                                                     Courses                                                   2015             Spring                            Hip-Hop Trails: Tracing and Rediscovering the Origins and Legacy of Hip-Hop Culture                  Thu      6:20 PM -      9:00 PM                                                   2013             Fall                            Hip-Hop Trails: Tracing and Rediscovering the Origins and Legacy of Hip-Hop Culture                  Fri      3:30 PM -      6:10 PM                                                   2012             Spring                            Social Enterprising: Redefining Social Change in the 21st Century                  Mon,Wed      3:30 PM -      4:45 PM                                                   2011             Spring                            Social Enterprising: Redefining Social Change in the 21st Century                  Mon,Wed      3:30 PM -      4:45 PM                                       Research and Teaching Interests       Social entrepreneurship/enterprising; Hip-Hop culture as a tool for education, organizing and social change; Hip-Hop history, archiving and cultural memory; Hip-Hop branding, consumerism and visual/media culture; women in Hip-Hop                                                                                                              NYU Gallatin Footer              Gallatin School of Individualized Study     1 Washington Place     New York, NY 10003     (212) 998-7370                   A–Z Index      Directions      Contact Us      Job Opportunities               News      Support Gallatin      Feedback                         Follow us on Facebook      Follow us on Twitter      Follow us on Youtube         Follow us Instagram                 Unless otherwise noted, all content copyright NYU Gallatin.
